commit_message:
Factor out common k8s definitions and mappings

Factor Out common kubernetes template definitions and address mapping
from Fedora Atomic, CoreOS and Suse drivers.

Partially-Implements: bp bay-drivers
Change-Id: Ib172c19acc1303041f7d8d9249df2d9ca1e4ff6f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/magnum refs/changes/86/365286/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: class AtomicK8sTemplateDefinition(template_def.K8sTemplateDefinition): self.add_output('kube_minions', bay_attr='node_addresses', mapping_type=NodeAddressOutputMapping) self.add_output('kube_masters', bay_attr='master_addresses', mapping_type=MasterAddressOutputMapping)
deleted_lines: KUBE_SECURE_PORT = '6443' KUBE_INSECURE_PORT = '8080'class K8sApiAddressOutputMapping(template_def.OutputMapping): def set_output(self, stack, cluster_template, bay): if self.bay_attr is None: return output_value = self.get_output_value(stack) if output_value is not None: # TODO(yuanying): port number is hardcoded, this will be fix protocol = 'https' port = KUBE_SECURE_PORT if cluster_template.tls_disabled: protocol = 'http' port = KUBE_INSECURE_PORT params = { 'protocol': protocol, 'address': output_value, 'port': port, } value = "%(protocol)s://%(address)s:%(port)s" % params setattr(bay, self.bay_attr, value) class K8sTemplateDefinition(template_def.BaseTemplateDefinition): """Base Kubernetes template.""" def __init__(self): super(K8sTemplateDefinition, self).__init__() self.add_parameter('master_flavor', cluster_template_attr='master_flavor_id') self.add_parameter('minion_flavor', cluster_template_attr='flavor_id') self.add_parameter('number_of_minions', bay_attr='node_count') self.add_parameter('external_network', cluster_template_attr='external_network_id', required=True) self.add_parameter('network_driver', cluster_template_attr='network_driver') self.add_parameter('volume_driver', cluster_template_attr='volume_driver') self.add_parameter('tls_disabled', cluster_template_attr='tls_disabled', required=True) self.add_parameter('registry_enabled', cluster_template_attr='registry_enabled') self.add_parameter('bay_uuid', bay_attr='uuid', param_type=str) self.add_parameter('insecure_registry_url', cluster_template_attr='insecure_registry') self.add_parameter('kube_version', bay_attr='coe_version') self.add_output('api_address', bay_attr='api_address', mapping_type=K8sApiAddressOutputMapping) self.add_output('kube_minions_private', bay_attr=None) self.add_output('kube_minions', bay_attr='node_addresses', mapping_type=NodeAddressOutputMapping) self.add_output('kube_masters_private', bay_attr=None) self.add_output('kube_masters', bay_attr='master_addresses', mapping_type=MasterAddressOutputMapping) def get_params(self, context, cluster_template, bay, **kwargs): extra_params = kwargs.pop('extra_params', {}) scale_mgr = kwargs.pop('scale_manager', None) if scale_mgr: hosts = self.get_output('kube_minions_private') extra_params['minions_to_remove'] = ( scale_mgr.get_removal_nodes(hosts)) extra_params['discovery_url'] = self.get_discovery_url(bay) osc = self.get_osc(context) extra_params['magnum_url'] = osc.magnum_url() if cluster_template.tls_disabled: extra_params['loadbalancing_protocol'] = 'HTTP' extra_params['kubernetes_port'] = 8080 label_list = ['flannel_network_cidr', 'flannel_backend', 'flannel_network_subnetlen'] for label in label_list: extra_params[label] = cluster_template.labels.get(label) if cluster_template.registry_enabled: extra_params['swift_region'] = CONF.docker_registry.swift_region extra_params['registry_container'] = ( CONF.docker_registry.swift_registry_container) return super(K8sTemplateDefinition, self).get_params(context, cluster_template, bay, extra_params=extra_params, **kwargs) class AtomicK8sTemplateDefinition(K8sTemplateDefinition):

Add Python 3.5 classifier and venv

Now that there is a passing gate job, we can claim support for
Python 3.5 in the classifier. This patch also adds the convenience
py35 venv.

commit_message:
Add craton-dashboard repository (Horizon Plugin)

Craton (Fleet Management) is a new proposed OpenStack project
that augments operating OpenStack clouds by providing scalable
device/host management:

This patch adds the repo "craton-dashboard".

Change-Id: I78fc25a29455cc3a01c58e6ce7ff0cf9e0b91baa

commit_message:
Fix module loading on centos hosts.

Introducing a new var: {{ openstask_host_module_file }} that contain
the path to the file containing module list.

Centos will use systemd-modules-load.service:
- http://www.unix.com/man-page/centos/8/systemd-modules-load.service/
- http://www.unix.com/man-page/centos/5/modules-load.d/

Change-Id: I9ce294045259752e48c47ed036a9550565f05bc5
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-openstack_hosts refs/changes/81/362881/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Fix tooltip updating logic

This commit fixes stuck tooltips for disabled buttons on
the deployment history control and everywhere where it could
be used in the same conditions. componentDidUpdate() method
of the Tooltip control was modified to handle all possible
situations.

Change-Id: Ifea56e087101096023c67ef26f1e1a8c83ab7712
Closes-Bug: #1620669

added_lines: componentDidUpdate(prevProps) { var newText = this.props.text; var oldText = prevProps.text; if (newText !== oldText) { if (!newText) { this.removeTooltip(); } else if (!oldText) { this.addTooltip(); } else { this.updateTooltipTitle(); }

commit_message:
Only admin can get actions with quotas

At present commands like 'cinder quota-defaults tenant_id'
(quota-show, quota-usage) display wrong info when tenant_id
is invalid. To check if the tenant-id/project-id is invalid
(or does not exist) the user should be admin. The test
test_quota_usage_after_volume_transfer invokes method get_defaults
in cinder/quota.py and if cls.alt_client is not admin he is not
authorized to perform the action to get project
(http://paste.openstack.org/show/558384/).

This patch is related to https://review.openstack.org/#/c/315673/

Change-Id: I2e6400330f5b1e2986cfb0ff86ea7c1c3ffa1e7b
Related-Bug: #1307487

commit_message:
Composable upgrades: cinder

Cinder-volume is kind of a special snowflake given that it can be
managed by pacemaker even in evolved HA arch (A/P on controllers) and
directly by systemd (e.g. on LVM block storage nodes), both in the same
deployment at the same time. So the cinder-volume role supports
upgrading such configurations.

Implements: blueprint overcloud-upgrades-per-service
Change-Id: I37a81c03131945824a9ef675dc3c80eff6033a87

commit_message:
Upgrades: structure and keystone upgrade

Adds basic structure for running new upgrades, and adds upgrade steps
for keystone.

See ansible/upgrades/README.rst for information about how to run the
upgrades by hand without automated integration with Mistral or Heat.

Change-Id: I89f564e1dfecb1d536ecbd86e9bda7cf3b4783fa

commit_message:
Composable Upgrades

Change-Id: Ief0accb5f41fc5a48e898f97d18ae7901297bcfb
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-specs refs/changes/64/319264/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode =================== Composable Upgrades =================== Include the URL of your launchpad blueprint: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/overcloud-upgrades-per-service With composable services and custom roles coming, we'll have to make upgrades composable too. Problem Description =================== Currently upgrades are monolithic, based around the 5 roles we have in TripleO (Controller, Compute, ...). The insufficiency of monolithic approach for the future is twofold: 1. With composable services, we won't be able to assume what services are deployed on our 5 roles. 2. With custom roles, we won't be able to assume what roles are present in the overcloud deployment. This means we cannot use the role based approach, as e.g. "role X must be upgraded before role Y" might not make sense anymore if one of the roles isn't present in the deployment, and we have some different added roles instead, and the assignment of services to roles is customizable. We'll have to switch to service based approach, or an approach somehow derived from services (e.g. a "component based" approach where a component is made of 1+ services). Furthermore it's questionable whether the combination of Heat + Bash is still manageable for performing the upgrades in such a freeform environment. We might want to rearchitect the upgrades approach completely and use a more workflow oriented rather than convergence oriented tool. Proposed Change =============== Overview -------- The proposed solution for composable upgrades utilizes Ansible. This means we'd export information about the overcloud via Heat stack outputs, and use this in Ansible upgrade tooling. This can also be considered fitting (or a step towards) the "split stack" model -- separating out the means of hardware vs. software configuration from a currently monolithic Heat stack. Required changes ---------------- - Per-role service manifest output from the overcloud stack. We'd have a map of roles, where the keys are their service manifests. Service manifest is a map of services, where the keys are maps of service properties. :) For example:: "role_services": { "controller": { "glance-api": {}, "glance-registry": {}, "rabbitmq": { "pacemaker-managed": true } }, "compute": { "nova-compute": {} } } This information would be utilized to find out which TripleO node roles would run which Ansible upgrade roles. .. The exact mechanics for making this happen are unclear at this point. As Mistral allows arbitrary computation via evaluation of javascript code, it could be used to generate Ansible snippets if we don't find a better solution. - Node IP addresses (on management network, per-role) output from the overcloud stack. For example:: "role_nodes": { "controller": ["192.168.10.5", "192.168.10.6", "192.168.10.7"], "compute": ["192.168.10.8", "192.168.10.9"] } This information would be used to create an inventory file for Ansible, probably via Mistral. - SSH access to the overcloud nodes for Ansible. (We already require SSH access for the current upgrade procedure of non-controller nodes.) - Ansible roles for upgrading. One role per service as defined in t-h-t service manifest. We need to support upgrading multiple services at the same time (e.g. glance-api and glance-registry must go together to match their messaging protocol). So upgrade will be done by executing the roles in steps, e.g. the main.yml file could look like:: # example of something that we want done in each step - include: gather_some_info.yml - include: stop.yml when: "{{ upgrade_step }}" == "stop_services" - include: upgrade.yml when: "{{ upgrade_step }}" == "upgrade_services" - include: start.yml when: "{{ upgrade_step }}" == "start_services" We'd execute the resulting play/playbook multiple times, each time with a different ``upgrade_step``. This is a way how we can interleave execution of Ansible roles. Alternative could be to have an Ansible role "per step per service", rather than just "per service", but that could get a bit heavy handed perhaps. - Mistral workflows and actions to automate the upgrade and perhaps serve as an information processing bridge between Heat and Ansible. It would be very handy to have an option to inspect or change what Mistral generated before triggering the upgrade process via Ansible. Open challenges and risks ------------------------- - How to process service manifests into an Ansible play/playbook that would serve as an upgrade plan. - The order of upgrading between components is a concern, and this knowledge has to be somehow captured and adhered to. - Especially challenging could be handling custom services which aren't present in tripleo-heat-templates and the default distribution of upgrade logic. Perhaps manually amending the upgrade plan (inserting custom plays into the correct spot in the playbook) could be a workable solution (perhaps somewhat similar to NIC template customization or resource registry customization). - How do we deal with parallelism the right way -- some services need to be upgraded in parallel everywhere (most of them), some shouldn't (e.g. nova-compute should be one-by-one and with breakpoints in between to reduce the chance of incapacitating all workloads at once in case there's a problem in the upgrade). - "Breakpoints" within Mistral workflows are probably necessary to provide a decent level of control for the operators. E.g. to manually amend "the upgrade plan" or to verify that previous nova-compute upgraded successfully before upgrading another one. - How do we capture the "components" -- service groups that need to be upgraded at the same time. - Given the amount of work for this spec to land fully, we should consider the possibility of slipping this feature into Ocata. Rationale documentation and alternatives ---------------------------------------- .. This is a verbose section to provide deeper understanding of the issues and the choices made. You can skip this when reading the spec as a reference of what got implemented. However, it's good to read when doing refactorings or suggesting improvements of the process. - Q: What tools should we use? Is the current mechanism involving Heat+Bash suitable, or should we switch to something different? - A: Investigating Ansible in more depth (PoC perhaps) sounds promising for this purpose. Heat is convergence-oriented and has limited composability options (list_join, map_merge) but upgrades are quite a "workflowy" issue. I didn't find a silver bullet tool for this, but Ansible could fit the task better than Heat+Bash. (Mistral to provide the REST API, Ansible to provide system management actions perhaps.) - Q: Where does the upgrade logic live? - A: tripleo-common could be a place to bootstrap the ansible roles and plays, but for old version support it would be more suitable to put upgrade logic to something that is release-specific, which is currently only tripleo-heat-templates. If putting Ansible roles into a repo that has "Heat" in its name sounds bad, we could create a separate repo and ship it as release-specific too. - Q: Should we: a) Perform upgrade of all services at the same time vs. b) go strictly service-after-service and requiring services to support that vs. c) select a subset of services to upgrade at the same time. -- What of these options are possible with OpenStack? What of these options could be made to work with TripleO and the tools we chose? What are the complexity impacts for upgrades implementation? - Upgrading everything everywhere in one leap sounds troubling (if something goes wrong with nova-compute upgrade in a single step, the whole cloud, incl. VMs, could be unavailable). - Going "strictly service-after-service" is most probably not possible. (Where service is understood as in t-h-t composable services sense, where "glance-api" and "glance-registry" are separate services). - A: We could maybe go component by component -- "first upgrade Keystone, then Glance (all services)". This means that of the above three options we need to pick the one called "c) select a subset of services to upgrade at the same time", which is probably going to be a bit harder to implement than b). - Q: Is a component-after-component upgrade even possible with packages? What if updating a single component pulls in some RPM update dependencies that will cause the not-yet-upgraded services to stop working? - A: Many guides (upstream, RDO, etc.) suggest that it should be possible. Perhaps it would be a good idea to not restart any unupgraded services until the upgrade is fully completed though. * Q: If we go from monolithic approach to a some form of a hook-based approach, where each service can export its own pieces of upgrade logic to be executed at various points during the upgrade, do we need to address ordering between services within a single hook? If so, how do we do that with the tool we chose? () - This is quite an inconvenient problem to solve. Of the existing tools we currently use or consider using, only Puppet is able to cope with micro-ordering like this. Implementing all upgrades in Puppet with a heap of ``exec`` could do this in theory, but it doesn't feel like the right thing to even start investigating. Puppet isn't meant to be used in such way (we'd be bending it into exec-focused rather than resource-focused tool). Implementing a new tool for action graph resolution (e.g. using Prolog) would be possible but integration with existing other tools like Ansible could be unclean and unfitting. Solving this problem calls for implementing a new middle-ground workflow/sysconfig tool, one that would be workflow focused rather than convergence focused, but allow much more complex composability ordering rules than the usual workflowy tools allow. - If we go with component-by-component upgrade utilizing the option "c) select a subset of services to upgrade at the same time", we still wouldn't have tight control over what comes first within a single component upgrade ("do i stop glance-api or glance-registry first"), but given that we assume services should be resilient towards various start/stop orderings in the evolved HA architecture (managing services directly in systemd rather than through pacemaker), this shouldn't be considered a problem in upgrades either. - If we still find ourselves in need of more ordering granularity even when doing component-by-component upgrades: a) it might be a bug in the component being updated that should be fixed b) we can try to split that component to smaller independently-upgradable components c) we may make the upgrade code for services of that component smarter (e.g. stop both services if they're present) d) we may need to add more upgrade steps (this option is not favorable). - A: This might be difficult to implement properly, hopefully it wouldn't be a very hot issue if we don't have micro-ordering, as there seem to be several ways how to mitigate the impact. - Q: For once-per-component operations, we might need the concept of a bootstrap node for a given component. Currently in Heat we only have a bootstrap node as one of the controllers, but that won't be sufficient with custom roles. How to do this? - A: Apparently Ansible solves this out of the box with ``run_once: true``. Security Impact --------------- Describe any potential security impact on the system. Some of the items to consider include: * Does this change touch sensitive data such as tokens, keys, or user data? * Does this change involve cryptography or hashing? * Does this change require the use of sudo or any elevated privileges? * Does this change involve using or parsing user-provided data? This could be directly at the API level or indirectly such as changes to a cache layer. * Can this change enable a resource exhaustion attack, such as allowing a single API interaction to consume significant server resources? Some examples of this include launching subprocesses for each connection, or entity expansion attacks in XML. For more detailed guidance, please see the OpenStack Security Guidelines as a reference (https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Security/Guidelines). These guidelines are a work in progress and are designed to help you identify security best practices. For further information, feel free to reach out to the OpenStack Security Group at openstack-security@lists.openstack.org. Other End User Impact --------------------- Are there ways a user will interact with this feature? Performance Impact ------------------ Describe any potential performance impact on the system, for example how often will new code be called, and is there a major change to the calling pattern of existing code. Examples of things to consider here include: * A small change in a utility function or a commonly used decorator can have a large impacts on performance. Other Deployer Impact --------------------- Discuss things that will affect how you deploy and configure OpenStack that have not already been mentioned, such as: * What config options are being added? Should they be more generic than proposed (for example a flag that other hypervisor drivers might want to implement as well)? Are the default values ones which will work well in real deployments? * Is this a change that takes immediate effect after its merged, or is it something that has to be explicitly enabled? * Please state anything that those doing continuous deployment, or those upgrading from the previous release, need to be aware of. Also describe any plans to deprecate configuration values or features. For example, if we change the directory name that instances are stored in, how do we handle instance directories created before the change landed? Do we move them? Do we have a special case in the code? Do we assume that the operator will recreate all the instances in their cloud? Developer Impact ---------------- Discuss things that will affect other developers working on OpenStack. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Who is leading the writing of the code? Or is this a blueprint where you're throwing it out there to see who picks it up? If more than one person is working on the implementation, please designate the primary author and contact. Primary assignee: <launchpad-id or None> Other contributors: <launchpad-id or None> Work Items ---------- Work items or tasks -- break the feature up into the things that need to be done to implement it. Those parts might end up being done by different people, but we're mostly trying to understand the timeline for implementation. Dependencies ============ * Include specific references to specs and/or blueprints in tripleo, or in other projects, that this one either depends on or is related to. * If this requires functionality of another project that is not currently used by Tripleo (such as the glance v2 API when we previously only required v1), document that fact. * Does this feature require any new library dependencies or code otherwise not included in OpenStack? Or does it depend on a specific version of library? Testing ======= Please discuss how the change will be tested. Is this untestable in CI given current limitations (specific hardware / software configurations available)? If so, are there mitigation plans (3rd party testing, gate enhancements, etc). Documentation Impact ==================== What is the impact on the docs? Don't repeat details discussed above, but please reference them here. References ========== Please add any useful references here. You are not required to have any reference. Moreover, this specification should still make sense when your references are unavailable. Examples of what you could include are: * Links to mailing list or IRC discussions * Links to notes from a summit session * Links to relevant research, if appropriate * Related specifications as appropriate (e.g. if it's an EC2 thing, link the EC2 docs) * Anything else you feel it is worthwhile to refer to

commit_message:
Set max-servers value to 150 for internap-mtl01

First shalt thou create a change. Then shalt thou set the value to 150,
no more, no less. 150 shall be the number thou shalt set, and
the value of the config shall be 150. 151 shalt thou not set,
neither set thou 149, excepting that thou then proceed to 150.

Change-Id: Id2969000d18f600da15866a4f58834267323cfe2

Change-Id: Ib72bcde9b32d3c0b4b237068aa53146f58ea10a2
"}]
commit_message:
Fix: Duplicated driver causes conductor to fail

This patch is fixing a problem which causes the conductor to get confused
and error out on startup in case there's a duplicated entry in the
enabled_drivers configuration option.

Closes-Bug: #1561564
Change-Id: Ib72bcde9b32d3c0b4b237068aa53146f58ea10a2
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic refs/changes/94/297194/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ENABLED_DRIVERS = set(CONF.enabled_drivers) if ep.name in ENABLED_DRIVERS: return ext.name in ENABLED_DRIVERS if (sorted(ENABLED_DRIVERS) != names = [n for n in ENABLED_DRIVERS if n not in found]
deleted_lines: if ep.name in CONF.enabled_drivers: return ext.name in CONF.enabled_drivers if (sorted(CONF.enabled_drivers) != names = [n for n in CONF.enabled_drivers if n not in found]

commit_message:
[DOC]Added Xenial support in install guide

Ensured that OSA installation guide caters for doing an installtion
both on latest release of ubuntu(16.04 Xenial) and 14.04 trusty as
well.

This patch adds 16.04 Xenial support in the docs of install guide.

Change-Id: I459b74db262d2b6bf88edd5b7e36faba0fe00ab3
Closes-Bug: 1619296

commit_message:
Adding config fixture

Adding config fixture, so that this can be used as mock data
for writing further unit tests for config and where all config
options are used.

Change-Id: I4f14886213e231179744afa8521ff9943a71cb76

commit_message:
Alarm monitor: Update Heat driver

Implements bp: #alarm-based-monitoring-driver

Change-Id: I3e1de2d6c39bfc6d9792e6e7549c39075578d03b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tacker refs/changes/21/347721/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # from tacker.vm.alarm_drivers.ceilometer_driver import ceilometer_driver def generate_hot_alarm_resource(topology_tpl_dict, heat_tpl): heat_dict = yamlparser.simple_ordered_parse(heat_tpl) is_enabled_alarm = False def _convert_to_heat_monitoring_prop(mon_policy_prop): tpl_trigger_name = mon_policy_prop['triggers']['resize_compute'] tpl_condition = tpl_trigger_name['condition'] properties = {} properties['meter_name'] = tpl_trigger_name['metrics'] properties['comparison_operator'] = tpl_condition['comparison_operator'] properties['period'] = tpl_condition['period'] properties['evaluations'] = tpl_condition['evaluations'] properties['statistic'] = tpl_condition['method'] properties['description'] = tpl_condition['constraint'] properties['threshold'] = tpl_condition['threshold'] # properties['actions'] = tpl_condition['alarm_actions']['resize'] # alarm url process here low_level_design = tpl_trigger_name['event_type']['implementation'] # TODO(anyone) extend to support any low level design. # TODO (tungdoan) Should be validate function: Ceilometer, Monasca, Definition if low_level_design == 'Ceilometer': properties['alarm_actions'] = '' # mon_policy['properties'] = properties return properties def _convert_to_heat_monitoring_resource(mon_policy_dict): name,mon_policy_prop = mon_policy_dict.items()[0] mon_policy_hot = {'type':'OS::Ceilometer::Alarm'} mon_policy_hot['properties'] = _convert_to_heat_monitoring_prop(mon_policy_prop) return mon_policy_hot if 'policies' in topology_tpl_dict: for policy_dict in topology_tpl_dict['policies']: name, policy_tpl_dict = policy_dict.items()[0] if policy_tpl_dict['type'] == 'tosca.policies.tacker.Alarming': is_enabled_alarm = True heat_dict['resources'][name] = _convert_to_heat_monitoring_resource(policy_dict) break heat_tpl_yaml = yaml.dump(heat_dict) return (is_enabled_alarm, heat_tpl_yaml) is_tosca_format = False is_tosca_format = True if is_tosca_format: (is_enabled_alarm, heat_tpl_yaml) = \ generate_hot_alarm_resource(vnfd_dict['topology_template'], heat_template_yaml) if is_enabled_alarm: heat_template_yaml = heat_tpl_yaml fields['template'] = heat_template_yaml return property_name in resource['attributes']
deleted_lines: fields['template'] = heat_template_yaml return property_name in resource['attributes']

added_lines: # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. # from oslo_config import cfg from oslo_log import log as logging import random import string from tacker.common import utils from tacker.vnfm.monitor_drivers import alarm_abstract_driver LOG = logging.getLogger(__name__) trigger_opts = [ cfg.StrOpt('host', default=utils.get_hostname(), help=_('Address which drivers use to trigger')), cfg.PortOpt('port', default=9890, help=_('number of seconds to wait for a response')) ] cfg.CONF.register_opts(trigger_opts, group='trigger') def config_opts(): return [('trigger', trigger_opts)] class VNFMonitorCeilometer(alarm_abstract_driver.VNFMonitorAbstractAlarmDriver): def get_type(self): return 'ceilometer' def get_name(self): return 'ceilometer' def get_description(self): return 'Tacker VNFMonitor Ceilometer Driver' def _create_alarm_url(self, vnf_id, mon_policy_name, mon_policy_action): # alarm_url = 'http://host:port/v1.0/vnfs/vnf-uuid/monitoring-policy-name/action-name?key=8785' host = cfg.CONF.trigger.host port = cfg.CONF.trigger.port LOG.info(_("Tacker in heat listening on %(host)s:%(port)s"), {'host': host, 'port': port}) origin = "http://%(host)s:%(port)s/v1.0/vnfs" % {'host': host, 'port': port} access_key = ''.join( random.SystemRandom().choice(string.ascii_lowercase + string.digits) for _ in range(8)) alarm_url = "".join([origin, '/', vnf_id, '/', mon_policy_name, '/', mon_policy_action, '/', access_key]) return alarm_url def call_alarm_url(self, vnf, kwargs): '''must be used after call heat-create in plugin''' return self._create_alarm_url(**kwargs)

git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tacker refs/changes/75/355975/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Copyright 2012 OpenStack Foundation # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. from oslo_serialization import jsonutils import logging from six.moves.urllib import parse as urlparse from tacker import wsgi from tacker.vm.monitor_drivers.token import Token LOG = logging.getLogger(__name__) class AlarmReceiver(wsgi.Middleware): def process_request(self, req): if req.method != 'POST': return url = req.url if not self.handle_url(url): return prefix, info, params = self.handle_url(req.url) device_id = info[3] self.validate_url(device_id) token = Token(username='admin', password='devstack', auth_url="http://127.0.0.1:35357/v2.0", tenant_name="admin") token_identity = token.create_token() req.headers['X_AUTH_TOKEN'] = token_identity # Change the body request if 'alarm_id' in req.body: body_dict = dict() body_dict['trigger'] = {} body_dict['trigger']['params'] = jsonutils.loads(req.body) body_dict['trigger']['policy_name'] = info[4] body_dict['trigger']['action_name'] = info[5] req.body = jsonutils.dumps(body_dict) LOG.debug('Body alarm: %s', req.body) # Need to change url because of mandatory req.environ['PATH_INFO'] = prefix + 'actions' req.environ['QUERY_STRING'] = '' LOG.debug('alarm url in receiver: %s', req.url) def handle_url(self, url): parts = urlparse.urlparse(url) p = parts.path.split('/') if len(p) != 6: return None if any((p[0] != '', p[2] != 'vnfs')): return None qs = urlparse.parse_qs(parts.query) params = dict((k, v[0]) for k, v in qs.items()) prefix_url = '/%(collec)s/%(vnf_uuid)s/' % {'collec': p[2], 'vnf_uuid': p[3]} return prefix_url, p, params def validate_url(self, device_id): '''Validate with db''' LOG.debug(_('Alarm url triggered: %s'), device_id) return True

subject: VMAX Driver - VMAX3 clone volume failure
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-06-10 07:37:50.000000000', 'files': ['cinder/volume/drivers/emc/emc_vmax_provision.py', 'cinder/volume/drivers/emc/emc_vmax_provision_v3.py', 'cinder/tests/unit/test_emc_vmax.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/6c53687ad32561c84dc1fa18116352d02cca86f5', 'message': 'VMAX Driver - VMAX3 clone volume failure

VMAX3 clone volume failure happens occasionally when
more than one thread is accessing the same storage
group at the same time. Extra locking has been put
around all config change operations involving storage
groups, to prevent this from happening.

Change-Id: Id6574d9e87a473ae5084ef39e341f4517758d66f
Closes-Bug: #1587654
'}]
commit_message:
VMAX Driver - VMAX3 clone volume failure

VMAX3 clone volume failure happens occasionally when
more than one thread is accessing the same storage
group at the same time. Extra locking has been put
around all config change operations involving storage
groups, to prevent this from happening.

Change-Id: Id6574d9e87a473ae5084ef39e341f4517758d66f
Closes-Bug: #1587654

Enable couchbase cluster support

capable database.

Added a couchbase cluster details page.

commit_message:
missing requirements of keystoneclient

The guests are missing a keystone client and therefore won't launch.

commit_message:
Add Tempest Run option to README

This patch adds "tempest run" as one of the options to run
the monasca tempest tests.

See bp tempest-run-cmd for details.

Change-Id: Idcfa09b86775642e5f3698d2a2ec8ffd7e39b817
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/monasca-api refs/changes/00/347500/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ## Run the tests using Tempest Run command ``tempest run`` is a domain-specific command to be used as the primary entry point for running Tempest tests. 1. In the Tempest root dir: ``` tempest run -r monasca_tempest_tests ```

commit_message:
Forbid legacy tasks only in LCM enabled clusters

In case we inherit old clusters, without LCM, we must not check their
plugins for legacy tasks to prohibit them.

Change-Id: I23dcc48cc1321d38666b8bcf7d435abd70ac9b61
Closes-Bug: #1620321

commit_message:
Fix pep8 errors when running with python3

This patch is replacing raw_input() with six.moves.input() because
raw_input is not present in python3+.

Fixing this also makes "tox -epep8" happy when running with python3.

Change-Id: If28f97b479fa018079c7d180541ca29689398a68
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-common refs/changes/24/365724/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Restore trust workaround for legacy auth

Before mitaka, we were not supporting keystone v3 and we were
expecting to have the auth_url ending with /v2.0 to ensure
v2 keystone API. We were using a workaround to force v3 for trust
keystone client, and when we moved to keystoneauth1 we removed this workaround
but it's still needed.

This change restores it. It ensures the endpoint is a v3 endpoint when
the user enter a v2 endpoint and set domain to 'default' that was the
only that worked before, because we were not really support keystone v3.

This is not a backport because it fixes a bug in deprecated (and already removed from master) code.

Closes-bug: #1620499
Change-Id: Idf474348ab4d49073dc5561caf90e151c4138819

added_lines: from keystoneauth1 import discover as ka_discover auth_url = conf[CFG_GROUP].os_auth_url try: auth_url_noneversion = auth_url.replace('/v2.0', '/') discover = ka_discover.Discover(auth_url=auth_url_noneversion) v3_auth_url = discover.url_for('3.0') if v3_auth_url: auth_url = v3_auth_url else: auth_url = auth_url except Exception: auth_url = auth_url.replace('/v2.0', '/v3') auth_url=auth_url,

commit_message:
Add List Roles Action

This patch adds an action which lists the roles in a deployment
plan.

Change-Id: I0cbd9217b892ed0b345d4150674e902e00b192c7
Co-Authored-By: Jeff Peeler <jpeeler@redhat.com>
Co-Authored-By: Dougal Matthews <dougal@redhat.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-common refs/changes/83/330283/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # For a given container, returns a list of Heat resources where # type = OS::Heat::ResourceGroup class ListRoleAction(base.TripleOAction): def __init__(self, container=constants.DEFAULT_CONTAINER_NAME): super(ListRoleAction, self).__init__() self.container = container def run(self): oc = self._get_object_client() dataMap = yaml.load( oc.get_object(self.container, 'overcloud.yaml')[1])['resources'] roles = [] for resource, details in dataMap.items(): if details['type'] == "OS::Heat::ResourceGroup": roles.append(resource) return roles

commit_message:
[docs] Revise Storage Architecture Overview

The Storage Architecture Overview is revised to include the new
diagrams and to use them to explain design considerations when
implementing a production OpenStack environment.

This patch includes the move of the storage diagrams to the new
location.

Change-Id: Ie63466b16e2d61b3d82f73462dbf709ae04e4994

commit_message:
Release xstatic-angular-smart-table 1.4.13.2

As part of the improvements to the xstatic management and release
process, we have been using an xstatic-release[1] script to help with
creation and sanitisation of these packages. Unfortunately, an oversight
meant that the metadata of these packages was invalid, causing
downstream packagers to be unable to use them. This release updates the
metadata without changing the content of the package.

Relevant IRC log:
http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/irclogs/%23openstack-release/%23openstack-release.2016-09-06.log.html#t2016-09-06T14:08:03

1. https://pypi.python.org/pypi/xstatic-release/1.2.1

Change-Id: I1433b5c984b0489351d04ac88e244f35ebb42c14

commit_message:
Handles http error parse of keystone

The Keystone json payload doesn't have the same format as Gnocchi
have. This change handles it instead of printing backtrace
because the field 'descriuption' does not exists.

Change-Id: If9640c77b0e796d81ebc21a1b705bfc8c496b432
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-gnocchiclient refs/changes/22/365922/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if 'description' in error: # Gnocchi format print(error['description']) elif 'error' in error and 'message' in error['error']: # Keystone format print(error['error']['message'])

that precedes each rest method clearly reflects the context of the
respective rest method.

Change-Id: I7b22063db7ff4807242cc0e353dccc34be848b8d
"}]
commit_message:
Include heat base profile outside of step

The base profile can already take the steps into account. so it's not
necessary to include it inside the if statement.

Change-Id: I7b22063db7ff4807242cc0e353dccc34be848b8d

commit_message:
Add Ceph RGW listener to HAProxy

Shares the same (ssl)port with Swift Proxy

Change-Id: I2e1de1a3fa6ad62895a1e972e43858f23c08bbea
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-tripleo refs/changes/16/362816/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # [*ceph_rgw*] # (optional) Enable or not Ceph RadosGW binding # Defaults to hiera('ceph_rgw_enabled', false) ## 'ceph_rgw_port' (Defaults to 8080) # 'ceph_rgw_ssl_port' (Defaults to 13808) $ceph_rgw = hiera('ceph_rgw_enabled', false), ceph_rgw_port => 8080, ceph_rgw_ssl_port => 13808, if $ceph_rgw { ::tripleo::haproxy::endpoint { 'ceph_rgw': public_virtual_ip => $public_virtual_ip, internal_ip => hiera('ceph_rgw_vip', $controller_virtual_ip), service_port => $ports[ceph_rgw_port], ip_addresses => hiera('ceph_rgw_node_ips', $controller_hosts_real), server_names => $controller_hosts_names_real, public_ssl_port => $ports[ceph_rgw_ssl_port], } }

commit_message:
Convert ringbuilder to build devices array

Currently we have some hard-coded mangling in t-h-t but we
instead need to build the array based on the nodes running swift
storage, combined with the SwiftRawDisks parameter.

This will enable running SwiftStorage on nodes other than Controller
and SwiftStorage roles, and is required for custom-roles due to
the hard-coded stuff in the role templates and overcloud.yaml

Change-Id: I11deed1df712ecccf85d36a75b3bd2e9d226af36
Partially-Implements: blueprint custom-roles
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-tripleo refs/changes/37/364737/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # (Optional) DEPRECATED The swift devices # Should pass raw_disk_prefix, raw_disks and swift_storage_node_ips instead# [*raw_disk_prefix*] # (Optional) Disk prefix used to create devices list # Defaults to 'r1z1-' # # [*raw_disks*] # (Optional) list of raw disks in format # [':%PORT%/device1', ':%PORT%/device2'] # Combined with raw_disk_prefix and swift_storage_node_ips # to create devices list # Defaults to an empty list # # [*swift_storage_node_ips*] # (Optional) list of ip addresses for nodes running swift_storage service # Defaults to hiera('swift_storage_node_ips') or an empty list # $raw_disk_prefix = 'r1z1-' $raw_disks = [], $swift_storage_node_ips = hiera('swift_storage_node_ips', []) if $devices { $device_array = strip(split(rstrip($devices), ',')) } else { # FIXME(shardy) - build the $devices list # we need to combine raw_disk_prefix, raw_disks and swift_storage_node_ips # e.g # raw_disk_prefix = 'r1z1-' # raw_disks = [':%PORT%/device1', ':%PORT%/device2'] # swift_storage_node_ips = ['192.168.1.12', '192.168.1.13',] # # devices should be ['r1z1-192.168.1.12:%PORT%/device1', # 'r1z1-192.168.1.12:%PORT%/device2' # 'r1z1-192.168.1.13:%PORT%/device1' # 'r1z1-192.168.1.13:%PORT%/device2'] $devices_array = prefix($swift_storage_node_ips. $raw_disk_prefix) # TODO zip/join devices_array with raw_disks? }

commit_message:
Add gnocchi ansible role

Partially-Implements: blueprint ansible-gnocchi

Change-Id: I8dd0460bd21ac0a233fab0142ec7b6079459bdc2
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla refs/changes/51/349351/52 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: {% set python_path = '/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages' if kolla_install_type == 'binary' else '/var/lib/kolla/venv/lib/python2.7/site-packages' %} Listen {{ hostvars[inventory_hostname]['ansible_' + api_interface]['ipv4']['address'] }}:{{ gnocchi_api_port }} <VirtualHost *:{{ gnocchi_api_port }}> ## Directories, there should at least be a declaration for /var/www/cgi-bin/gnocchi <Directory "/var/www/cgi-bin/gnocchi"> Options Indexes FollowSymLinks MultiViews AllowOverride None Require all granted </Directory> ## Logging ErrorLog "/var/log/kolla/gnocchi/gnocchi_wsgi_error.log" ServerSignature Off CustomLog "/var/log/kolla/gnocchi/gnocchi_wsgi_access.log" combined WSGIApplicationGroup %{GLOBAL} WSGIDaemonProcess gnocchi processes=5 threads=1 user=gnocchi group=gnocchi python-path={{ python_path }} WSGIProcessGroup gnocchi WSGIScriptAlias / /var/www/cgi-bin/gnocchi/app WSGIPassAuthorization On <IfVersion >= 2.4> ErrorLogFormat "%{cu}t %M" </IfVersion> </VirtualHost>

commit_message:
Replace deprecated rabbitmq parametrs

This patch replace rabbitmq deprecated
paramters with transport_url.

https://github.com/openstack/oslo.messaging/blob/master/oslo_messaging/_drivers/impl_rabbit.py#L112,#L134
https://github.com/openstack/oslo.messaging/blob/master/oslo_messaging/transport.py#L46
https://github.com/openstack/oslo.messaging/blob/master/oslo_messaging/_drivers/impl_rabbit.py#L163,L174

Change-Id: Idbac8aefe9b624d4c386283174fd5fd47a1545b2
Closes-Bug: #1620477
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla refs/changes/94/365894/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: transport_url = rabbit://{% for host in groups['rabbitmq'] %}{{ rabbitmq_user }}:{{ rabbitmq_password }}@{{ hostvars[host]['ansible_' + hostvars[host]['api_interface']]['ipv4']['address'] }}:{{ rabbitmq_port }}{% if not loop.last %},{% endif %}{% endfor %}
deleted_lines: rpc_backend = rabbit[oslo_messaging_rabbit] rabbit_userid = {{ rabbitmq_user }} rabbit_password = {{ rabbitmq_password }} rabbit_ha_queues = true rabbit_hosts = {% for host in groups['rabbitmq'] %}{{ hostvars[host]['ansible_' + hostvars[host]['api_interface']]['ipv4']['address'] }}:{{ rabbitmq_port }}{% if not loop.last %},{% endif %}{% endfor %}

commit_message:
Plugins v 5.0.0 support in plugins adapters

Now it is possible:
* To bring release as plugin
* To define multiple graphs types for the plugin

Change-Id: Idcac14e6f4055ca0e488efc2cc23945036a493d9
Implements-Blueprint: release-as-a-plugin

commit_message:
Fixed assumed utility pip install for specific clients

This change implements a dynamic lookup and installation of python clients
within the utility container. The purpose of this change is to ensure that only
python clients known to the environment are installed within the utility
container.

Change-Id: I60e79f3017a5ad3eec6ffca36839acf50fbdf3ce
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>

commit_message:
Unify getting properties for method of Server res

Method .get() allows to specify default value. Hovewer it's not used
here and ad extra step, before execute simple call props[key].
Also other similar calls does not use .get(), so let's unify it too.

Change-Id: I045a01f7eedbc8093f84c301adb8573aa812dae6

commit_message:
[WIP] Add Segment CLI to NeutronClient

This patch adds the CLI support for Segments in NeutronClient.

Change-Id: Ibd833064d6616961851e441017db48dfdcd8caf5
Depends-On: I0a198545ba02e5db25c25355feff763257696075
Partially-Implements: blueprint routed-networks
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-neutronclient refs/changes/67/290267/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Copyright 2016 NEC TECHNOLOGIES LTD. # All Rights Reserved # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. # from neutronclient._i18n import _ from neutronclient.neutron import v2_0 as neutronV20 class CreateSegment(neutronV20.CreateCommand): """Create a segment for a given tenant.""" resource = 'segment' def add_known_arguments(self, parser): parser.add_argument( '--description', help=_("Description of the segment.")) parser.add_argument( '--name', help=_("Name of the segment.")) parser.add_argument( '--network', help=_("ID or name of the Network which is associated " "with this segment.")) parser.add_argument( '--network-type', help=_("Physical mechanism by which the segment's network" " is implemented.")) parser.add_argument( '--physical-network', help=_("Name of the physical network over which this segment is" " implemented.")) parser.add_argument( '--segmentation-id', help=_("VLAN ID for VLAN networks or tunnel-id for GRE/VXLAN" " networks")) def args2body(self, parsed_args): body = {} if parsed_args.network: body['network_id'] = neutronV20.find_resourceid_by_name_or_id( self.get_client(), 'network', parsed_args.network) if parsed_args.name: body['name'] = parsed_args.name if parsed_args.description: body['description'] = parsed_args.description # ToDo(reedip):Name and Description are not a part of the actual CRUD. # However discussion is still ongoing, so if in the end # Name and Description are required, they can be moved # or removed otherwise. neutronV20.update_dict(parsed_args, body, ['network_type', 'physical_network', 'segmentation_id']) return {self.resource: body} class DeleteSegment(neutronV20.DeleteCommand): """Delete a given segment.""" resource = 'segment' class ListSegments(neutronV20.ListCommand): """List segments that belong to a given tenant.""" resource = 'segment' list_columns = ['id', 'network_id', 'segmentation_id'] pagination_support = True sorting_support = True class ShowSegment(neutronV20.ShowCommand): """Show information of a given segment.""" resource = 'segment'

commit_message:
Use babel-plugin-transform-runtime instead of babel-polyfill

babel-plugin-transform-runtime allows to reduce size of the
resulting bundle dramatically (from 260kb to 24kb).

Change-Id: I3cceb1caddfb5b0b2048b7d4efc2cebfee26ab91

commit_message:
Align the stars to promote Ci to latest Newton

1) Promote RDO to latest trunk
2) Configure puppet-keystone to manage credentials, as it's now required
   by keystone upstream.
3) Run Zaqar tests against API v2 (1.0 is deprecated and 1.1 will be
   deprecated soon).

Depends-On: I364f65c7009e400f2851e37999e1d8c0b6f5fd5a
Change-Id: I967038c872628a5a290e2890641c9c8dac45588d

commit_message:
Update ironic-multinode job timeout

This patch increases ironic-multinode timeout to 180min. This timeout is
configured on ironic-multitenancy job, since multinode job using the same
tests and configuration as ironic-multitenancy we using the same value.

Change-Id: I18bf2445fb594e50f5eb38adf56d01142aee25e4
Closes-Bug: #1620349

added_lines: def test_deployment_history_include_summary(self): fake_history = utils.get_fake_deployment_history(include_summary=True) matcher = self.m_request.get( self.get_url( nodes='1,2', statuses='ready,error,pending', tasks_names='controller-remaining-tasks,' 'ironic-compute,pending-task' ) + '&include_summary=1', json=fake_history) tasks_after_facade = self.client.get_all( transaction_id=self.transaction_id, nodes=['1', '2'], statuses=['ready', 'error', 'pending'], tasks_names=['controller-remaining-tasks', 'ironic-compute', 'pending-task'], include_summary=True, show_parameters=False ) self.assertTrue(matcher.called) self.assertItemsEqual( utils.get_fake_deployment_history(convert_legacy_fields=True, include_summary=True), tasks_after_facade)

commit_message:
Clean up FakeClient classes in volume fakes

Put FakeTransferClient and FakeServiceClient classes
into FakeVolumeClient class, I think we need not to
create FakeClient classes for every objects, we can use
only FakeVolumeClient for all volume objects. This can
reduce repetition, unified codes and make codes look
cleaner and easier.

Change-Id: I2729ef0e80166f4d49ccd9a48b653e2f215e3bfe

added_lines: function generate_testr_results { if [ -f .testrepository/0 ]; then sudo .tox/functional/bin/testr last --subunit > $WORKSPACE/testrepository.subunit sudo mv $WORKSPACE/testrepository.subunit $BASE/logs/testrepository.subunit sudo /usr/os-testr-env/bin/subunit2html $BASE/logs/testrepository.subunit $BASE/logs/testr_results.html sudo gzip -9 $BASE/logs/testrepository.subunit sudo gzip -9 $BASE/logs/testr_results.html sudo chown jenkins:jenkins $BASE/logs/testrepository.subunit.gz $BASE/logs/testr_results.html.gz sudo chmod a+r $BASE/logs/testrepository.subunit.gz $BASE/logs/testr_results.html.gz fi } set -xe EXIT_CODE=$? generate_testr_results exit $EXIT_CODE

commit_message:
Cinder::Volume observe reality implementation

Add override parse_live_resource_data method implementation to
OS::Cinder::Volume resource.

implements bp get-reality-for-resources

Change-Id: Ifa6f4e7d01e8a146eaaf5d38f229346a27f1981e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat refs/changes/45/261445/13 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def __init__(self, name, definition, stack): super(CinderVolume, self).__init__(name, definition, stack) self._availability_zone = None vol = self.client().volumes.get(self.resource_id) self._availability_zone = vol.availability_zone def _get_live_state(self, resource_properties=None): super(CinderVolume, self)._get_live_state( resource_properties=resource_properties) if not resource_properties: msg = _('There is no resource properties data to update ' 'inner properties of resource %s.') % self.name raise ValueError(msg) volume_reality = {} try: volume = self.client().volumes.get(self.resource_id) volume_data = volume._info except Exception as ex: if self.client_plugin().is_not_found(ex): raise exception.EntityNotFound(entity='Resource', name=self.name) raise # Check availability zone and decide to add or not to add it to # resulting dict. az = volume_data['availability_zone'] if resource_properties.get(self.AVAILABILITY_ZONE) is not None: volume_reality.update({self.AVAILABILITY_ZONE: az}) elif self._availability_zone != az: volume_reality.update({self.AVAILABILITY_ZONE: az}) # Update read_only property from resource properties in case of # impossibility of getting it from cinder API. volume_reality.update( {self.READ_ONLY: resource_properties.get(self.READ_ONLY)}) # Check image and decide how to add it to resulting dict. resource_image = resource_properties.get(self.IMAGE) if resource_image: data_image = volume_data.get('volume_image_metadata') if data_image is not None: rsrc_image_id = self.client_plugin( 'glance').get_image_id(resource_image) data_image_id = self.client_plugin( 'glance').get_image_id(data_image) volume_reality.update({self.IMAGE: resource_image if rsrc_image_id == data_image_id else data_image}) else: volume_reality.update({self.IMAGE: None}) # Update reality data with scheduler hints. hints = resource_properties.get(self.CINDER_SCHEDULER_HINTS) if hints is not None: volume_reality.update({self.CINDER_SCHEDULER_HINTS: {}}) for hint in hints: if volume_data.get(hint) is not None: volume_reality[self.CINDER_SCHEDULER_HINTS].update( {hint: volume_data.get(hint)}) props_keys = [self.SIZE, self.SNAPSHOT_ID, self.NAME, self.DESCRIPTION, self.VOLUME_TYPE, self.METADATA, self.SOURCE_VOLID, self.MULTI_ATTACH, self.BACKUP_ID] for key in props_keys: volume_reality.update({key: volume_data.get(key)}) return volume_reality

subject: Update release configs with temporary file server IP
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-09-02 18:40:54.000000000', 'files': ['config/release/liberty.yml', 'config/release/master.yml', 'config/release/newton.yml', 'config/release/mitaka.yml'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-quickstart/commit/e8d4af4f679f59ee52716a5a2bc2c74e3a49f34a', 'message': 'Update release configs with temporary file server IP

The ci.centos artifacts server was recently rate limited for
downloads, and this makes tripleo-quickstart pretty much unusable.

We have stood up a simple web server to host the files temporarily,
while we explore better options. This patch switches the default
image locations in the release configs to point to this new location.

Change-Id: I802b379b299c7e4232feed54273dc1919b968eae
'}]
commit_message:
Update release configs with temporary file server IP

The ci.centos artifacts server was recently rate limited for
downloads, and this makes tripleo-quickstart pretty much unusable.

We have stood up a simple web server to host the files temporarily,
while we explore better options. This patch switches the default
image locations in the release configs to point to this new location.

Change-Id: I802b379b299c7e4232feed54273dc1919b968eae
